light source.source: The UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectrum (UV-vis-DRS) was measured using a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrometer and transformed into an absorption spectrum according to the Kubelka-Munk relationship.
light source.context: Ni(NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O (99) and Al(NO 3 ) 3 9H 2 O (99) were both obtained from Aladdin and used as the precursors for NiAl-LDH.Ti 3 AlC 2 and ammonium fluoride were obtained from Macklin.Hydrofluoric acid and urea were supplied by Aladdin, and all other chemicals used in the experiments were purchased from the Shanghai Chemical Reagent Company. Ti 3 C 2 was prepared by selectively etching the Al atoms from Ti 3 AlC 2 in a HF solution (40) 34.The obtained Ti 3 C 2 was rinsed repeatedly with deionized water and dried under vacuum. Fig. 1(a) displays the in situ loading of Ti 3 C 2 on NiAl-LDH.The obtained Ti 3 C 2 (1 g) was dispersed in DMSO (100 ml) and stirred overnight.Then, the powder was separated and sonicated in ionized water.The suspension was centrifuged for 1 h.The supernatant was collected, and the concentration of Ti 3 C 2 was determined to be 15 mg/mL.The Ti 3 C 2 dispersion was mixed with Ni(NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O (0.87 g), Al(NO 3 ) 3 9H 2 O (0.375 g), NH 4 F (0.592 g) and urea (2.4 g).The mixture was sonicated and vigorously stirred for 0.5 h.Then, the solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave (100 mL) and kept at 120 C for 24 h.During the crystallization process, Ti 3 C 2 was deposited on the scaffold of NiAl-LDH.The obtained sample was washed alternatively with deionized water and alcohol.In this manner, NiAl-LDH/Ti 3 C 2 hybrids with different volumes of Ti 3 C 2 dispersions (10, 30 and 60 ml) were obtained and denoted LDH/TC-1, LDH/TC-2 and LDH/TC-3.For comparison, bare NiAl-LDH without the modification by Ti 3 C 2 was also prepared using the same procedure. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements of the samples were conducted on a Brucker D8 diffractometer with a Cu Ka radiation source.The sample morphologies were investigated using a field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, HITACHI S-4800) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS, Oxford instruments X-Max).Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded using an FEI Tecnai F20 microscope at an accelerating voltage of 100 kV.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a PHI-5000C ESCA system (Perkin-Elmer) with Mg K radiation (h 1253.6eV).The UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectrum (UV-vis-DRS) was measured using a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrometer and transformed into an absorption spectrum according to the Kubelka-Munk relationship. The specific surface areas and pore diameter distributions were measured using nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K obtained with an automatic surface area analyser (Micromeritics Tristar-3000, USA).Photoluminescence (PL) emission spectra were recorded using a PerkinElmer LS 55 Fluorescence spectrometer at 355 nm.The photoluminescence (PL) decay profiles were obtained using a Horiba Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog-3-21-TCSPC spectrometer. The photocatalytic performance of the catalysts was evaluated under irradiation by a 300 W Xenon arc lamp.In each test, the sample (0.1 g) and deionized water (0.4 mL) were introduced as the reducer.The reaction setup was filled with highly purified CO 2 gas to achieve adsorption-desorption equilibrium prior to irradiation.Then, the lamp was turned on for 6 consecutive hours.During irradiation, approximately 1 mL of gas was removed for subsequent analysis performed using a gas chromatograph (GC-2014, Shimadzu Corp., Japan) that is equipped with both FID and TCD detectors.The carrier gas was high-purity Ar gas.The isotope-labelled experiments were performed using 13 CO 2 and H 2 18 O as the reactants, and the products were analysed using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (QP2010SE, Shimadzu Corp., Japan). Transient photocurrent and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy measurements were performed using a CHI760E electrochemical workstation.A standard threeelectrode configuration was applied, and 0.5 M Na 2 SO 4 solution was used as the electrolyte.Fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glass coated with the sample was used as the working electrode.Pt sheets and a saturated calomel electrode (SCEs) were used as the counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively.The measurements were operated at open-circuit potential.A sinusoidal ac perturbation of 5 mV was applied to the electrode over the frequency range from 0.01 Hz to 10 kHz.The XRD pattern for NiAl-LDH (Fig. 1b) displays the characteristic features of hydrotalcite-type compounds.The diffraction peaks at 11.3, 22.8, 34.6, 39.0, 46.2, 60.2 and 61.5 are assigned to the (003), (006), ( 012), ( 015), (018), ( 110) and (113) planes, respectively, and are in accordance with the standard (JCPDS 22-0452) 32.
